title: Star History Monthly Jan 2024 | Underrated Open Source Projects
author: Mila
excerpt: We are taking a look at some underrated open source projects that deserve more recognition.

title: Introducing Star History Forum
author: Tianzhou
excerpt: Introducing star-history forum

title: Starlet #18 Prisma ORM: Simplify Working and Interacting with Databases
author: Nikolas Burk
excerpt: Prisma ORM is a toolkit that makes it easy for developers to work with databases, and is committed to creating a great developer experience for developers that are building data-driven applications.

title: Star History Best of 2023
author: Mila
excerpt: Time for an End of Year Review of our favourite open-source projects that stood out in 2023!

title: Starlet #17 SpiceDB: Google Zanzibar-inspired Authorization System
author: Pablo Macias
excerpt: SpiceDB is an open source, Google Zanzibar-inspired database for creating and managing security-critical application permissions.

title: Star History Monthly Jan 2024 | Open-source Text2SQL Tools
author: Mila
excerpt: Text2SQL, or Chat2SQL tools convert natural language or questions into SQL queries. Imagine having ChatGPT write beautiful, correct and useful SQL queries for you!

title: Starlet #16 Apache Answer: Thrive the Community. Unleash Collective Knowledge.
author: Anne Zhu
excerpt: Apache Answer is an open-source Q&A platform software for teams at any scale, now incubating in Apache Software Foundation.

title: Star History Monthly Dec 2023 | Open-source GPT Wrappers
author: Mila
excerpt: GPT wrappers offer a service by wrapping around ChatGPT API to provide an additional functionality not offered directly by OpenAI itself.

title: Starlet #15 Infinity: the AI-Native Database Powering the Next-Gen RAG for LLM
author: Yingfeng Zhang
excerpt: Infinity is an AI-native database specifically designed to cater to large models and is primarily used for Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG).

title: Star History Monthly Nov 2023 | Open-source Text To Speech Engines
author: Mila
excerpt: Text To Speech, or TTS, is a part of human-computer dialogue that enables machines to speak, here are a few open-source TTS options to look at.

title: Starlet #14 Proton: A streaming SQL analytical engine, powered by ClickHouse
author: Jove Zhong
excerpt: Proton is a new open-source streaming SQL analytical engine that combines the power of OLAP processing with responsive real-time streaming analytics.

title: Starlet #13 Earthly: Fast, consistent builds with an instantly familiar syntax - like Dockerfile and Makefile had a baby
author: Gavin Johnson
excerpt: Earthly is like a combination of Docker and Make, running build scripts in Docker containers for consistent results in any environment.

title: Star History Monthly Oct 2023 | Open-source AI Extensions for Postgres
author: Mila
excerpt: Postgres extensions can add extra functionality to your database, and we're sharing five Postgres extensions that just might boost your AI experience.

title: Starlet #12 Wasp: the fastest way to develop full-stack web apps with React & Node.js
author: Matija Sosic
excerpt: Wasp is a fully open-source, full-stack web framework for React, Node.js, and Prisma

title: Starlet #11 libSQL: SQLite for modern applications
author: Glauber Costa
excerpt: libSQL is an Open Source and Open Contribution fork of SQLite

title: Star History Monthly Sep 2023 | Open-source GitHub Copilot alternatives
author: Mila
excerpt: One of the places where AI has made a major breakthrough is in helping with coding. Here, we gathered a few open-source AI coding assistants to boost your productivity.

title: Starlet #10 PostgresML: The GPU-powered AI application database
author: Montana Low
excerpt: PostgresML is the first GPU-powered AI application database - build chatbots, search engines, forecasting apps and more with the latest NLP, LLM and ML models using the simplicity and power of SQL.

title: Starlet #9 Electric SQL - Build reactive, realtime, local-first apps directly on Postgres
author: Sam Willis
excerpt: Use ElectricSQL to build super fast, collaborative, offline-capable apps directly on Postgres by syncing to a local SQLite database.

title: Do GitHub stars ‚≠êÔ∏è = Money üí∞?
author: Nevo David
excerpt: Open source projects are starting out by collecting GitHub stars, but stars are not coins, contributors, or customers. So why are we trying to collect them?

title: Starlet #8 Prompt flow - Developer Tool for Building High-Quality LLM Applications
author: Jie Tong
excerpt: Fresh open-sourced by Microsoft, Prompt flow is a suite of devtools designed to streamline the end-to-end development cycle of LLM-based AI applications.

title: Star History Monthly Pick | CLI Tools for Working with LLMs
author: Mila
excerpt: This time we are taking a look at a few open-source CLI tools for working with ChatGPT and other LLMs.

title: Starlet #7 Clipboard ‚Äì Remember Anything, Anytime, Anywhere at Breakneck Speed
author: Jackson Huff
excerpt: The Clipboard Project is a new and upcoming open source tool designed to supercharge your productivity by making it easy to remember anything, anytime, anywhere.

title: Starlet #6 Hoppscotch - The Open Source API Platform for Developers
author: Liyas Thomas
excerpt: Launched as an open-source alternative to Postman, Hoppschotch's goal is to build a lightweight API request builder that works for everyone regardless of their system specification to test their APIs.

title: Starlet #5 MetisFL - the blazing-fast and developer-friendly federated learning framework
author: Panagiotis Kyriakis
excerpt: MetisFL is an open-source federated learning framework that makes it easy for developers and enterprises to train their models on distributed data sources.

title: The (Detailed & Creative) Playbook for Getting More GitHub Stars
author: Zevi Reinitz
excerpt: A team that just launched an open source tool for developers shares their first-hand experience on how to grow your own project.

title: Star History Monthly Pick | Llama 2 and Ecosystem Edition
author: Mila
excerpt: Meta released Llama 2 in July, which can be freely used for research and commercial purposes. We are taking a look at some open-source options to get started with Llama 2 on your own machine.

title: Starlet #4 chatgpt.js - Client-side JavaScript library for ChatGPT
author: Adam Lui
excerpt: chatgpt.js is a JavaScript library that supports this ecosystem by allowing for super-easy interaction with the ChatGPT DOM.

title: Dify - LLMOps platform, Define your AI-native apps
author: Dify.AI
excerpt: Dify.AI is an open source LLMOps platform to unleash the full potential of GPT and other language models.

title: Starlet #3 Mockoon - Mock your API in seconds
author: Guillaume (255kb)
excerpt: Mockoon is a versatile API mocking tool with a desktop application and a CLI. It is simple and easy to use, yet powerful and heavily customizable.

title: Starlet #2 DLTA-AI - Data Labeling, Tracking and Annotation with AI
author: Usama Ahmed
excerpt: DLTA-AI is the next generation of annotation tools, integrating the Computer Vision SOTA models to Labelme in a seamless expirence and intuitive workflow to make creating image datasets easier than ever before.

author: Mila

title: Add a live star-history chart to your GitHub README
author: Steven
excerpt: Now we support embedding a live star history chart into your GitHub README. This feature is quite handy. A snippet would appear after querying the repository from our star-history.com main page; the only thing you need to do is simply copy that snippet into your GitHub README markdown file.

title: Introducing the new star-history.com
author: Steven
excerpt: After a month of hard work, we are happy to introduce you to the new star-history.com. It has been rebuilt using a modern tech stack while keeping the original sketching / xkcd feel. Besides, we have added several highly requested features...
